description.narrative:
Alif Ailaan is the brand name for the three year education campaign funded by DFID under the "Transforming Education in Pakistan" programme. The campaign is based on a decade-long engagement between DFID and education stakeholders in Pakistan from 2001 to 2011 that essentially determined the need for a dramatic change in the level of active political engagement on education issues. The theory of change for the project is that a greater degree of political salience for education is a prerequisite for any transformational change to take place in education in Pakistan.
The state of Pakistan's education crisis is uncontested. There are currently 25 million children between ages five and sixteen that are out of school. The campaign has three key audiences: politicians and political parties, education providers (including teachers and administrators) and finally, Pakistani parents. Each audience is approached using different techniques, and the sum total of effort is designed to yield a fundamental change in the way the mainstream Pakistani political discourse deals with the education challenge. As long as the education crisis can be passed onto "the development people" it will continue to suffer from low investment (Pakistan spends only 1.9% of its GDP on education), and from low accountability (teacher absenteeism is a chronic problem, often hovering at 20%).
There are five core strands that the campaign depends on to enhance education's standing in the mainstream political discourse: Direct political advocacy, the media, civil society and direct community engagement, research and evidence and finally, the international community. Several pioneering efforts have been tested by the Alif Ailaan campaign and less than a year into operation, the campaign is already recognised as a trailblazer in areas like education and school infrastructure league tables for districts, cross platform activism and engaging senior journalists and politicians.
